urls.title: Thames Estuary 2100: 10-Year Review monitoring key findings
urls.description: We use some essential cookies to make this website work. We‚Äôd like to set additional cookies to understand how you use GOV.UK, remember your settings and improve government services. We also use cookies set by other sites to help us deliver content from their services. Where we have identified any third party copyright information you will need to obtain permission from the copyright holders concerned. This publication is available at https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/thames-estuary-2100-te2100/tha

tweets.text:
Today @EnvAgency launches its 10 yr monitoring report into #ClimateEmergency related changes to the #Thames Estuary. By incorporating findings to the @TE2100Plan we are adapting to a more #ClimateResilient future. #TogetherForOurPlanet #RaceToResilience
https://t.co/Y9mD2SZ2zl https://t.co/JhF760gcsB

It shows the importance of regulation in allowing industry to thrive while protecting air, land and water. 

Read the full report here - https://t.co/qDmR5R6ZSy https://t.co/jvZwAb1Vd7

I'll be away from the #ThamesBarrier for a few weeks. Plan to be back on Tuesday 23rd March.

I may not be available to reply to tweets for a few weeks or post about tidal conditions that may impact our operations.

Please follow @EnvAgencySE while I'm away for important updates. https://t.co/bsAAKX9wCu

urls.title: Community information about Coastal Defences at Chiswell and West Bay ‚Äì Dorset Coast Forum
urls.description: The Dorset Coast Forum, in partnership with the Environment Agency and Dorset Council, has released an updated version of the ‚ÄòStorms and Coastal Defences at Chiswell‚Äô booklet. The storms witnessed at the end of January prompted an update to the booklet which was originally released in 2014 after recent winter storms. The booklet was produced for Chiswell residents on Portland to help inform the community on what to do in a storm event, explain how the coastal defences work and what may happen in the

tweets.text:
Poor old @EnvAgency the wheels really are coming off the bus.

2019/20 target for "Kms of rivers enhanced", 2,300. 

Achieved? 1,753. Oops.

Target for 20/21 3,900.

Achieved in Q1? 31. Yes, that's right 31. Double oops.

PS. Can anyone tell me what "Enhanced", actually means? https://t.co/oa1m2WCN5V

urls.title: Am I at Risk? | The Flood Hub
urls.description: 1 in 6 properties in England are at risk of flooding from rivers, sea and surface water, with many others susceptible to various sources of flooding. This number is only set to increase due to climate change, making the need for you as a property owner to check your own risk ever more important. A variety of information is available to help you check your flood risk, from online data maps to risk management information, giving you a head start to prepare your property for potential flooding.

tweets.text: As the country saying goes - red sky in the morning shepherds warning.  We are expecting a wet and windy 48hrs and @EnvAgencyNW teams are prepared - you can find out how to prepare at https://t.co/jKVsuatlSD https://t.co/A0jKpdRS3B

@EnvAgency This is a dangerous line to tread... we‚Äôve seen that here in #NorthFerriby where the developer is boasting that the site will have 40% open space. It already exists. It is the Wolds Way & the meadow next to it is the village‚Äôs buffer. Only 60 steps from a home to the warehouse

urls.description: UK Climate Resilience Programme Webinar Series 2021 24 February 2021 Speakers: Paul Sayers (Sayers and Partners); stakeholder response from Mike Steel Chair: Jason Lowe Register for the webinar Abstract CAT modelling was developed in the late 1980s to capture the spatial correlation of extreme events, with event footprints being used to demonstrate how an extreme [‚Ä¶]
